AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: One of the more interesting hybrids on campus is the Freeman Maple [Acer x freemanii ‘Autumn Blaze’], also known as the Autumn Blaze Maple. This tree is a hybrid between the Silver Maple and the Red Maple and takes the best characteristics of each tree. The Autumn Blaze Maple at Winona State has the brilliant orange-red fall color similar to that of the Red Maple and grows faster than the Red Maple. The Autumn Blaze Maple also has drought tolerance and the ability to grow in most soils, as does the Silver Maple. The leaves of the Freeman Maple ‘Autumn Blaze’ give a spectacular show in the fall and the color is long-lasting. New growth on this tree stays red even after the leaves drop, and persists throughout winter and into spring. Native to the Midwest and eastern North America, Silver and Red Maples can now be found across most of the United States. The Autumn Blaze cultivar was introduced in 1987. The tree develops an oval crown that can grow to 50 feet tall and 40 feet in width. It grows uniformly and therefore requires very little pruning. One of Winona State University’s ‘Autumn Blaze’ Maples is conspicuously located just to the east of the front entrance to Somsen Hall, near the intersection of Johnson and Sanborn Streets.
Gray bark, smooth and thin in youth, becoming slightly furrowed with age.
Globular clusters of inflorescences in early spring.

some cultivars are fruitless; when present, the fruit is more similar to the Silver Maple than the Red Maple; 2 joined samaras per stalk, having semi-divergent wings, in pendulous clusters from the stems; maturing to yellow-brown in April-May.
Green simple, 3-5 lobed leaf blades; more similar to the Silver Maple than the Red Maple; autumn color - yellow or red, vibrant.

The Autumn Blaze Maple has the brilliant orange-red fall color similar to that of the Red Maple and grows faster than the Red Maple. The autumn Blaze Maple also has drought tolerance and the ability to grow in most soils, as does the Silver Maple.
